column1: #Text=Tour of notable villas in Esino Lario
#Text=The tour of notable villas in Esino Lario is a walking through the village of Esino Lario in the Italian province of Lecco .
#Text=Esino Lario became a travel destination from the late 19th century .
#Text=Initially most of the visitors were geologists using the village as a base when hiking the Grigna Mountains looking for fossils .

#Text=From the 1930s and peaking in the 1960s/70s , it was a preferred holiday location for citizens of the not-far-away city of Milan , who nicknamed Esino as La perla delle Grigne ( the Pearl of Grigne Mountains ) .
#Text=Several villas were built by the most affluent holiday-makers .
#Text=This tour takes you to the most notable ones .
#Text=This itinerary does not require any special preparation .
#Text=It can be easily walked : wear comfortable shoes as you will be walking uphill and downhill .
#Text=Most villas are still privately owned and can only be observed outside .
#Text=Villa Clotilde ( hosting the Tourist Office ) and Villa Gilardi ( nowadays a hotel with restaurant ) are the exceptions .
#Text=The ideal starting point is piazzale Gulfi ( Gulfi square ) at the side entrance of the city hall ( in Italian : Municipio ) .
#Text=The square has a parking lot for about 30 cars .
#Text=Leave Gulfi square going eastward in viale Adamello , uphill along the main road ( SP 65 ) .
#Text=You find the first villa on the right , when the road has the first bend : it is Villa Confalonieri having an imposing cedar in the middle of the garden .

#Text=A few meters ahead on the same street , still on the right , there is the entrance gate of Villa Gilardi ( aka Villa Gigi ) built in 1930s by Gilardi family and later transformed into the present hotel with restaurant named Rosa delle Alpi ( Alpin rose ) .
#Text=The same property also owns the next stop of the tour , la Madonnina , just after the right bend .
#Text=It was originally a building to host winders ( for textile industry ) .
#Text=Keep walking on the main road until reaching Villa Luzzani , named after its designer and original owner , Pietro Luzzani Rebaj .
#Text=Not far away , the next stops are Villa Acquali and Villa Gilera .
#Text=The last of the two was built by entrepreneur Giuseppe Gilera , who founded the namesake motor company .
#Text=Left Villa Gilera , the road takes you to a viewpoint where you can see Villaggio Riva ( Riva village ) on the mountain in front of you .
#Text=It was built between 1936 and 1942 by Bernardino Riva who became the first major of Esino Lario at the end of WWII .
#Text=The village counts twelve villas , each having a garden with an amazing view over the Esino valley .
#Text=From the viewpoint , we should go back for about one hundred meters and turn right in Montefiori street .
#Text=Where the street has a hairpin turn , we can find Villa Clotilde .
#Text=It was built by the Cazzaniga family and later became public owned and was transformed into the cultural centre of Esino Lario .
#Text=It hosts the Pietro Pensa Archive , the Tourist Office and the city library .
#Text=The building in the garden is , as of 2016 , home for the Museum of the Grigne .
#Text=In front of Villa Clotilde is Villa Silva , the first one in Esino with a tennis court , built in 1930s .
#Text=Going ahead on Montefiori street we are back to the main road .
#Text=Next to the crossing point , there is Villa Santopietro : it is among the oldest built in Esino .
#Text=The fresco on the east wall , representing Saint George , is remarkable .

#Text=Leaving Montefiori street , turn left in Don Rocca street where there is , on the left side , Villa Minuccia , designed by architect Mino Fiocchi for sculptor Michele Vedani , author of the high-reliefs of the Way of the Cross located along the street towards San Vittore church .

#Text=Before the Way , just in front of San Nicolao church and war memorial , there is the last stop of the tour : Villa delle Marcelline whose name recalls the fact that the original owner donated the villa to the nuns of Santa Marcellina in the early 1930s .
#Text=Before ending the tour loop , it can be worthwhile to keep walking on the street till you get to San Vittore church .
#Text=To go back to the parking area in Gulfi square , return to San Nicolao church .
#Text=On the right side of the church there is a descending street : at the end of the street , on the left , there is the starting point .
#Text=San Nicolao street is a stepped one : to avoid it , as alternative route , go backward from the church to la Montanina where turning right on the main road you can walk to the Gulfi square .
